INTERNATIONAL A3-17

The C.I.A. is giving the contras blueprints of public utilities and other installations the rebels will seek to destroy in raids deep inside Nicaragua, according to American Government officials. Page A1
The White House narrowly won a Senate vote that blocked cutting off a final installment of $40 million of military aid for the Nicaraguan rebels this year. The vote for the funds was 52 to 48. A10

A speeding of an Iran-contra inquiry is in prospect because the Senate and House investigative committees agreed to hold joint hearings. They also decided to grant limited immunity to Oliver L. North and John M. Poindexter. A1

Saudi Arabia offered secret aid to the Nicaraguan rebels in 1984, Robert C. McFarlane disclosed in letters written to his lawyer and 3 members of Congress before his suicide attempt last month, his lawyer said. A8
The U.S. seeks better Canada ties. President Reagan said he would ask Congress for $2.5 billion, a major spending increase, over five years for emission-control projects to battle acid rain. A3

Israel is curtailing ties with Pretoria including a halt in signing new military sales contracts in response to pressure from the United States Congress and American Jews, Israeli Cabinet officials said. A1
A Saudi diplomat was freed 66 days after he was kidnapped in West Beirut. The freed envoy, Bakr al-Damanhuri, met reporters at the home of Lebanon's Justice Minister, Nabih Berri. A3

A bomb killed four Filipinos and wounded 38 at a military academy where President Corazon C. Aquino is to speak this weekend. Some reports said ''disgruntled military elements'' might have placed the device. A17
Improved Bonn-Moscow ties were urged by Chancellor Helmut Kohl. The West German leader also called for a swift American-Soviet agreement to ban medium-range nuclear missiles from Europe. A6

A crisis in undersea competition with Moscow has prompted the Navy to complete a sweeping revision of its program for hunting the quiet submarines that the Kremlin has been increasingly constructing. A19
Manic-depressive illness is a group of disorders and either of at least two genetic defects may produce the illness, according to scientists who studied five large families in Jerusalem. A20

NATIONAL A18-23, B8-11, D26-27

Michael K. Deaver was indicted by agrand jury on charges of lying to Congress and the panel investigating his multimillion-dollar lobbying business. The former White House aide had been rebuffed in his appeal to Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist to block the indictment. A1
Speed limits would be increased to 65 miles an hour from 55 miles on rural interstate highways under a bill approved in the House, 217 to 206. The Senate passed the measure, 65 to 33, on Feb. 3. A18

An AIDS prevention campaign to deter Americans from the sexual and needle-injection practices that can spread the lethal virus is growing more vigorously and more desperately around the country. A1 U.S. bishops began unusual meetings with the Pope and senior Vatican officials in intensive and uncommonly long talks to seek success for John Paul II's visit to the United States next September. A18

The F.A.A. chief is resigning, effective in July. Efforts of the chief, Donald D. Engen, to rebuild the flight control system and manage booming airline traffic have been frustrated by events and politics. B11

An airline anti-collision device has been installed in a regular passenger flight for the first time. The Piedmont test system is designed to alert pilotsand, if necessary, flash an escape maneuver. B11 Training of school administrators in many colleges was faulted by a national panel. Such training should be halted, the panel said, because they lacked the ability to achieve educational excellence. D27
New designs of furniture and buildings are visual metaphors - witty variations of cars, animals and people. One architect has shaped a restaurant's chandeliers as huge crocodiles and fish. C1

Embattled judge sees vindication

High stakes for Reagan tonight Robertson and confidentiality Regional B1-7
Two construction unions agreed place many of their leaders and undergo supervision by a court-appointed trustee, under an arrangement set by Federal prosecutors after major racketeering trials. B1
12 LaRouche aides were arrested on charges of fraudulently obtaining money from donors to causes espoused by the extremist, Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., including $846,000 from New Yorkers. B4
A bus rear-door safety system plagues the New York City Transit Authority despite repairs. The interlock problem has resulted in nine accidents and two passenger deaths since 1984. B3

More doctors are selling the drugs they prescribe to patients in the New York metropolitan area. The practice is supported by the Federal Trade Commission, the American Medical Association and state medical societies. B1
A foster boy was moved 10 times in his five years in New York City's overwhelmed system. Most of the children are poor minority members thrown into a system of last resort by domestic breakdowns. A1
The Windsor jewels went on view to the public for the first time. By the thousands, people thronged the display of the Duchess's storied collection in Sotheby's galleries in Manhattan. A1
